node.text:
Our home in Connecticut is a Greek revival from 1844, so we are quite interested in how more modern architecture relates to ancient models.  Here I stand before one of the homes of Harbi Ibrahim, who kindly granted his permission for me to talk about a mud-brick house that has been in his family for several generations.  These houses are survivals of earlier architectural forms and are increasingly rare in Upper Egypt, as traditional mud-brick constructions are replaced by fired brick and concrete.  With this video, I hope to help promote the cultural heritage of Egypt, both ancient and modern (much like my earlier post about zar amulets). One of the texts that I reference is a New Kingdom love poem, and I quote here from John's translation of the eighth poem of the first group in the Papyrus Harris cycle of love poetry: "The towered villa of my sister, its door in the middle of her demesne, its double door leaves open—The monkey is about to get out, and my sister is going ape.  Oh were I made her gateman; I would make her angry at me, so I could hear her voice, when she goes ape.  Through fear of her I shall become a child." Bekhen is the term for a towered structure, such as a temple pylon, here in the sense of a turreted villa.  The bekhen is the ancestor of the pyrgoi, the tower-augmented farmhouses so prominent in Egyptian documents of the Graeco-Roman period.  We also discuss this love poem in our YouTube video "Cat Humor in Ancient Egypt," and we are excited to announce that this week, we will be giving an "Egyptomania" house tour in our next YouTube video.
.
Shoes by @americanduchess 
.
#ancientegypt #historichome #antiquehome #egyptologist #1920s #1920sfashion #cloche #truevintage #historyofarchitecture #arthistory

node.text:
A preview of our YouTube video that will debut this afternoon (stay tuned for an announcement in stories when it is live!). We both wear 1930s vintage as we discuss and read passages from the Litany of Re.  If you haven't seen our videos introducing the Valley of the Kings, you may want to check those out.  In this video, we explain where the Litany of Re occurs, and its overall meaning as praise of the sun god Re, including the 75 forms in the Great Litany.  We focus on two addresses - Address 56 and 69.  Address 56 is to the "Great Cat," and here we give you an excerpt of our translation of Address 69 to the Netherworldly Baboon.  These addresses show how just a few epithets and phrases can conjure entire cycles of ancient Egyptian myths, and also how reading hieroglyphic texts is essential to interpreting iconography.  The Netherworldly Baboon form of Re is particularly interesting because Re is essentially worshipping himself.  In Egyptian beliefs, baboons typically adore the sun god at sunrise (this seems to be based on observations of baboons in nature), so to be a Netherwordly baboon is to predict the sun's rise, hence creating an endless cycle.  Preserving the solar cycle is at the heart of ancient Egyptian religion.  If you want to be able to follow along with some of the signs, you can review the basic signs @howtoreadhieroglyphs and our How to Read Hieroglyphs video on YouTube. 
.
My dress is from @missvioletvixen. 
.
#1930s #1930svintage #historichome #egyptologists #egyptology #ancientegypt #egyptianreligion #valleyofthekings #stylishacademic

node.text:
A short video from this past summer of the Vintage Egypt tour by @tribexdigital @itskhalifa__ featuring us at the Cataract Hotel, the Winter Palace, and the SS Sudan on the Nile (turn your phone for landscape). Modern tourism, owing much to the enterprise of the recently deceased Thomas Cook company, continued and updated a long history of foreign visitors to Egypt. During the Graeco-Roman Period, a number of interesting visitors immortalized themselves, none perhaps so directly as the visit of the imperial entourage under the emperor Hadrian, whose text crowd one another on the base of the northern colossus of Amenhotep III on the west bank of Thebes (the colossus of Memnon). Another visitor was the medical student and esoteric scholar Thessalus of Tralles. Journeying from Anatolia, in Alexandria he attempted—with disappointing results—to resurrect the magic of Pharaoh Necho II. Undeterred, he removed himself to Thebes, where, probably through incubation in the sanatorium at Deir el-Bahari, he tells us (or a pseudepigraphic attributed to him does) that the visual and aural manifestation of Asclepius-Imhotep revealed to the medical student important zodiacal and planetary associations of certain herbs. We cannot guarantee a divine manifestation, but one never knows—join us in June on our next vintage adventure (full details in bio link!).
.
#vintagetravel #vintageegypt #historichotel #truevintageootd #vintageadventure #vintagehotel #1920s #1920sfashion #1930s #1930sfashion

node.text: The Elkab expedition house we share with the Royal Museums of Art and History, Brussels, was designed by the British architect Somers Clarke, based to a large extent on the Byzantine era monastery of Saint Simeon on the west bank of Aswan.  Here, on the east bank of Aswan, we foxtrot beneath the central dome of the 1902 Restaurant at the @softiellegendoldcataract, its architecture inspired by the Cordoba mosque, itself only a bit more recent than the monastery.  The name of modern Aswan is the Arabic version of the Graeco-Roman Syene, deriving from the ancient Egyptian Swenet, the settlement on the east bank of the Nile.  Opposite the Old Cataract hotel is the island Elephantine, a Greek translation of Egyptian Abu, “elephant (island),” a reference to the site as an ivory emporium (not to some imaginary resemblance of granite boulders to bathing elephants, as occasionally suggested). On the west bank, beyond the southern tip of Elephantine, is Gebel Tingar, topped by an anvil-shaped rock that is covered with rock inscriptions. A stela of "King" Hatshepsut once stood atop the hill, describing the riches of the south that once flowed into Aswan, the "door of the south." Important officials in the area during the Old Kingdom bore the title “sealers of the god,” people responsible for the goods of religious significance such as ostrich feathers and leopard skins that flowed into the city.  In the early twentieth century Arthur Weigall noted that when one tired of the bands and gowns of the Aswan hotels, the spirits of the ancient carvaneers waited atop Gebel Tingar; alas the jazz bands have departed, but the Cataract Hotel remains, along with the spirits of Sabni, Harkhuf, and other ancient explorers. I wear a 1930s evening gown from @shopmorphew, John's 1930s dinner jacket is from @raysragtimehollywood (vest and trousers from @vintagevirtuosa). This amazing footage was captured by @hsn08 @tribexdigital.  If you want to join us on another amazing trip, Vintage Nile, takes place December 10-18 (link in bio or DM me to your email to be added to the mailing list).

node.text: The title of a book by Barbara Mertz (aka Elizabeth Peters, author of the Amelia Peabody novels), "Red Land, Black Land" is also the topic of my inaugural IGTV video. Here I stand—in the late afternoon after a very toasty day of work—at the boundary between the desert, the Red Land, and the cultivable land, the Black Land, adjacent to the Nile Valley. The geomorphological backdrop then leads me down a path about Egyptian kingship and the conflict between Horus and Seth.  In the genealogy of the Heliopolitan Ennead (the nine deities who represent the totality of the Egyptian differentiation of one into many balanced pairs, the essence of Egyptian creation), Geb and Nut give birth to the siblings Osiris, Isis, Seth, and Nephthys.  At some point during Osiris' reign over Egypt as divine king, Seth murders him In later versions, the fratricide becomes dismemberment as Seth strews pieces of Osiris' corpse throughout Egypt.  The roots of this mythic cycle go back into the Pyramid Texts, but the blow-by-blow recording of events is only found in Greek sources two thousand years later, thus some of the episodes are almost certainly later developments. Despite Seth's role in the murder of Osiris, Seth is not evil personified—to find out who fills that role in Egyptian religion, stay tuned through the end of this video.

node.text:
I'm thrilled to be partnering with @varsitytutors again to explore what it was like to grow up in Ancient Egypt.  The mummies, pharaohs, and pyramid builders of Ancient Egypt were all children once. And believe it or not, their childhoods were in some ways similar to our own! Join me on August 26 at 7PM EST to learn what games Ancient Egyptian children played, what clothing and hairstyles were popular, how they interacted with their pets, and much more. To register for free, visit the link in my bio (https://bit.ly/3lNm6ar). This lecture is geared for 3rd to 7th graders, but if you are interested in learning more about an often overlooked aspect of ancient Egypt, I think this will be enjoyable for all!
.
In the lecture, I will discuss what sorts of pets the ancient Egyptians had, especially dogs.  Cats were also popular pets, and were normally called miu "cat," whereas dogs received names like people.  Here, with one of our two basenji dogs, Narmer, I study two images of children from ancient Egypt (which I will discuss in more detail) - Nakht and his family fishing and fowling in the marshes, and Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and their daughters in the palace.  The curly-tailed basenji breed was popular in ancient Egypt, but they also had a variety of hound breeds.  More exotic pets are also known, from gazelles to even Ramesses II's pet lion that accompanied him in battle!  Join me on August 26th for a free lecture to learn more!
.
#varsitytutors #ad #ancientegypt #ancienthistory #freeonlineclasses #learningisfun #egyptology #egyptologist #distancelearning #starclass

node.text:
Walking through the Italian Gardens of Castle Hill wearing a dress ca. 1910-1915 (available from @shopmorphew) in another amazing collaboration with @genuinegentleman.  The juxtaposition of the white crochet and lace with the light blue embroidery is reminiscent of Josiah Wedgwood's Jasperware that often replicated classical motifs.  Wedgwood could not have known that during the reign of Amunhotep III (1390-1352 BCE), a favorite ceramic style was cream-slipped or marl jars with blue-painted motifs that often featured plant designs. running horses, girls in papyrus skiffs, and calves frolicking in the marshes.  Applied decoration could include sculpted gazelles or the head of Hathor (thus some of the same imagery we discuss in the previous reel, featuring red 20s swimwear). The blue paint of the late 18th Dynasty vessels is remarkable for possibly being a synthetic pigment, "cobalt blue," made "through precipitation from a hydrous solution of alum and a soluble cobalt compound with ammonium or sodium carbonate as precipitants." (D. Arnold and J. Bourriau, An Introduction to Ancient Egyptian Pottery, p. 101). As Colin Hope has suggested, the ancient Egyptians sourced their alum from Dakhla and Kharga oases.  Far flung resources to create art extended to ancient Egyptian gardens as well.  The "Botanical Garden" chamber of Thutmose III at Karnak Temple shows how plants from all over the Middle East were collected to create a living work of art, much like the Italian Gardens through which I stroll. 
.
Location: @craneestate_trustees
Event: @roaringtwentieslawnparty
.
#edwardianfashion #roaringtwentieslawnparty #craneestate #castlehill #edwardiandress #italiangarden #wedgwood #neoclassical #ancientceramics #ancientpottery

node.text:
Continuing the swimsuit theme, bejeweled by @azzafahmy I wear a 30s Jantzen two-piece from @diggerodellvintage on the balcony of our favorite room at the @sofitellegendoldcataract. This is at twilight, a period for which the ancient Egyptians had several terms (one being akhekhou), when the sun still shines low on the horizon of the high desert, the Nile Valley basking in the afterglow. Behind me is Elephantine island, ancient Abu, and in the distance to the west (just to the left of my head) is Gebel Agg. A large boulder there has attracted many rock inscriptions, and at some point a dry stone enclosure was set up, with some free standing monuments, including a stela of  Hatshepsut mentioning trade from the far south. A quarry road snakes up past the site, and a route to the far south begins here as well, at the traditional border of Egypt. As A.E.P. Weigall once wrote: "When the amusements of the luxurious hotels have given out, and the solemnity of the ancient ruins has begun to pall, the spirits of Harkhuf and Sabna, of the captains and caravan-conductors, are always to be found waiting on the breezy hill-tops behond the island of Elephantine, at the head of the Nubian highway.”
.
#azzafahmy #oldcataract #vintagetravel #ancientegypt #vintageswimwear #truevintage #vintagestyle #elephantine #aswan #thisisegypt

node.text:
One of my new favorite vintage ensembles is this entirely original 1920s swim set.  The swim cap still has its tag (fortunately on the right side!) and the swim boots are from @gypsynationvintage.  The swimsuit (from @fabgabs) was made ca. 1925 and is the find of a lifetime (and a birthday present from John) made by the Bradley knitting company, with art deco koi fish.  A beautiful genre of objects from the Eighteenth Dynasty, many dating to the reign of Amunhotep III, depict young women swimming, holding in their outstretched hands a symbol that is also a receptacle for a cosmetic or scented ungent (another theory suggests that the more fragile wooden spoons were used for ritual water dispensing). The symbols that the girls hold can change, but all of them relate to the Egyptian New Year or re-birth, and now, the beginning of August, is just after the time that the ancient Egyptians observed the helical rising of Sirius and celebrated the beginning of the new year.  So one girl holds an antelope, one of the animal manifestations of Hathor, or another a duck, appropriate to the marshy environment where couples celebrated the New Year.  A tilapia fish with lotus blossoms coming from its mouth can even replace the swimming girl as the handle of the cosmetic spoon; the tilapia and lotus together symbolize rebirth, and the lotus cluster can be used in a cryptographic hieroglyphic writing of "true of voice," an epithet of a soul that passes the judgment of the weighing of the heart.  Studying such clusters of images together is key to understanding the function and meaning of objects manufactured over three thousand years ago!
.
Also featuring 1930s beach pajamas from @sugarviolette, a vintage parasol, and a parasol from @lily.lark.  Thanks to @alberto.urcia for his help.  Lots more photos of this shoot to come!
.
#egyptologist #1920s #vintageswimwear #vintageswimsuit #1920sstyle #artdeco #vintageswimcap #maxsennettbathingbeauty #classichollywood

node.text:
A portrait by the amazingly talented @liobabrueckner inspired by Gustav Klimt's 1901 painting of Judith holding the head of Holofernes.  Klimt's model was Adele Bloch-Bauer, and he blends the flat gilded aspects of Byzantine painting and mosaic arts in the background and attire, with more traditional perspective portraiture in the elements of her body.  Klimt also blends the image of the righteous indignation of Judith against Nebuchadnezzar's invading general Holofernes with their New Testament opposites, the sexually charged blood-lust of Salome with the head of John the Baptist.  The image confused enough critics that he ensured that the painting's frame bore the title "Judith und Holofernes." Klimt was well acquainted with the aspective Egyptian style as well in evidence from his depiction of Egypt in the form the goddess Isis and numerous identifiable Egyptian images and artifacts in an intercolumniation in the great staircase of the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.  In that painting, from 1891, the nude goddess Isis is the counterpart to the goddess Athena. 
.
Follow @liobabrueckner where she provides links to where you can see step-by-step tutorials of how she made this incredible piece.  I can't wait to hang a print on my wall!
.
#watercolorpainting #gustavklimt #klimt #vintageegyptologist #watercolor #colorpencil #portraitdrawing #traditionalart #isis

node.text:
From a magical shoot with @jschulten wearing a 1920s robe de style (from @fabgabs) paired with a pearl-encrusted headpiece (from @amandasatticvintage) and shoes (@adelinesattic) from the same date.  I stand on a marble staircase (in Connecticut). A robe de style is a dress that eschewed the more columnar appearance of many dresses of the 1920s.  Employing panniers, either built into the dress (as here) or worn as a separate undergarment, these dresses evoke the more voluminous skirts of the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries.  In its frontal width, but narrow side profile, this dress more specifically resembles those of seventeenth century Spain.  Ancient Egyptian women, as far as we can tell, did not employ any such devices, but the traditional flared men's kilt with starched front is a nice parallel.  During the New Kingdom, some soldiers wore large heart-shaped sporrans that may have been quilted.  Another element of clothing that appears to have been stiffened in order to stick out from the body is a set of wings and tail feathers of a large falcon.  This appears most prominently protruding somewhat awkwardly from the king's short jubilee robe in scenes of Amunhotep III's first celebration of that festival as depicted in the tomb of the official Kheruef, with at least one parallel dating to the Archaic Period. 
..
#1920s #truevintage #egyptologist #ancientegypt #dresshistory #costumehistory #historyofcostume #ancienthistory #1920sdress #robedestyle #historyofdress

node.text:
Standing among monumental statues of Hatshepsut, the daughter of a king, sister of a king, wife of a king, and seven years into the reign of her nephew Thutmose III, a king herself.  We know about her remarkable life through the study of not just her monuments, but above all hieroglyphic texts.  In the autobiography of Ineny, he describes how at the death of her husband and the coronation of Thutmose III, "the god's wife Hatshepsut was in control of the land, the two lands under her command." At Hatshepsut's temples, she tells us how Amun-Re chose her to rule Egypt as pharaoh, the proper successor of Thutmose I, and how she restored Egypt's temples that had fallen into ruin. 
.
But to read any of these hieroglyphic texts, you have to start with the basics of the ancient Egyptian language.  Do you want to learn where to begin?  I'm so excited to be partnering with @VarsityTutors and offering a FREE live class this Thursday at 3PM EST.  You will learn the orientation of hieroglyphs, their three uses, and even how to write the name of the king buried in the Great Pyramid!  Of course, Hatshepsut will be there too.  Sign up now by visiting the link in my bio! (the free registration will also allow you to access a recording if you cannot make the live event) #VarsityTutors #AD.
.
And please ask in the comments below anything you want to know about Hatshepsut's rule or her nephew Thutmose III! 
.
#egyptologist #ancientegypt #hieroglyphs #hieroglyphic #historygram #ancientcivilization #hatshepsut #ancienthistory

node.text:
A portrait by the amazing @rcallahanphoto @thevintageshow wearing all 1920s: cloche from @gingermegsv, dress from @gypsynationvintage, and 1920s jade and lapis lazuli necklace and lace gloves.  In the comments below, let me know what types of vintage ensembles you want to see me wear this summer or ask a question about ancient Egyptian or 1920s fashion! 
.
The colorful wool embroidery on my dress evokes the most famous decorated textile from ancient Egypt: a tunic from the tomb of Tutankhamun (Carter no. 367j), with an ankh-shaped neck opening decorated with the king's coronation name, Nebkheperure, palmettes, and patterned designs.  Most of the decoration is woven, but at least one band is embroidered; some of his other tunics also have tapestry panels (as someone who teaches a lot of art history, I find this ironic since the Bayeux Tapestry is actually an embroidery!). If you go back to a previous reel of John and me on the terrace of the Winter Palace, you can read about some of the exciting new research being done in the Grand Egyptian Museum conservation labs on textiles from the tomb of Tutankhamun.  I encourage everyone to follow @thezayinitiative that has incredible digital resources and a lecture series that explores the Art of Arab Dress, with its rich embroidery traditions. 
.
#1920s #embroidery #fashionhistory #costumehistory #ancientfashion #1920sdress #cloche #ancientegypt #arthistory #arthistorian

node.text:
From a shoot with @ninagalicheva.nyc with Mario (a black Percheron) and Foxy (a grey Shire, 20 hh), part of the herd @bluestar_equiculture.  The elegant gig that I drive is part of a multi-millennia old tradition of two-wheeled carts and carriages that also include one of the most important war machines of the Bronze Age: the chariot.  Between 1500 and 1100 BCE, the major powers of the eastern Mediterranean, including the Egyptians, Hittites, and Mitanni, fielded large chariot forces.  Chariots are often misunderstood as ancient tanks, as if 1) a horse would charge into infantry and 2) you were willing to throw away an incredibly expensive machine, horses, and trained soldiers to take out a few of the enemy!  Instead, chariots were initially used as mobile archer's platforms and remained so for the Egyptians.  Egyptian chariots had two-man crews: a driver/shield-bearer and the archer.  The horses, always stallions, were intensively trained, and Egyptians may have used something similar to the famous Hittite training manual written by a Mitanni horse trainer named Kikkuli.  Chariots, potentially moving at 20-25 miles per hour, could be driven across the front of enemy lines, while the archers rapidly fired.  Lightly armored infantry, called "runners" in Egyptian, served as support for the chariots.  By the 19th Dynasty, some of these runners are captured Sherden, one of the groups that the Egyptians called the "Sea Peoples." Invasions of Sea Peoples may be one of the major causes of the end of the Bronze Age, a topic of debate, but one I find endlessly fascinating, and you can read my contribution to the field on my Academia.edu page: The Great Karnak Inscription of Merneptah: Grand Strategy in the 13th Century BC.
.
#equestrian #chariot #equestrianstyle #ancienthistory #militaryhistory #ancientmilitary #horsesofinstagram #percheron #shirehorse

node.text:
Who wants to learn how to read hieroglyphs? I'm thrilled to be partnering with @VarsityTutors to offer a FREE live class all about these language tools! If you've ever dreamed of being an Egyptologist, this is your chance — we'll try writing and decoding hieroglyphs, as well as debunking some popular myths about them. Sign up now by visiting the link in my bio! #VarsityTutors #AD
.
What do you want to learn about ancient hieroglyphs?  Post in the comments below!!
.
Following several centuries of iconographic precursors, the Upper Egyptians develop the hieroglyphic script around 3250 BCE. Hieroglyphs then continue until 394 CE, when the last dateable hieroglyphic inscriptions is written at Philae Temple by a Nubian priest. The script involves a combination of phonetic signs, logograms (word signs), and determinatives (sometimes used like emojis). Tune in for this and much more!!! And in the meantime you can review some of the basics @howtoreadhieroglyphs. 
.
#egyptologist #ancientegypt #hieroglyphs #hieroglyphic #historygram #ancientcivilization

node.text:
Embodying the constellation of Greek and Roman moon-goddesses renowned for their hunting prowess, at the same time overseeing the dreams and inspiration of moonbeams.  My pose derives from early Classical (ca. 500 BCE) kneeling statues of archers, such as the Amazon archer from the Temple of Apollo at Eretria, and Herakles and Paris from Aegina. In later classical mythology and its more recent reimaginings, the old Titan goddess Selene (sister of Sun and Dawn), Roman Luna, Greek huntress Artemis, her Roman counterpart Diana, and the three-faced goddess of magic Hecate have all been somewhat conflated, along with the various other beings associated with them (so in Baroque paintings, we find Diana and Endymion, though the latter was originally beloved of Selene). I continue that trend here, wearing a mid-19th century Zari fabric pinned as a chlamys (Greek cloak that might be a hunter's only garb), holding a bow and arrow of the same date, with a crescent-shaped amulet on my forehead. More early 19th-century Zari billows above my head billows out to reveal a divine epiphany, in the Roman style of  velificatio. 
.
When going off to an evening event, be it dancing or battling the chaos titan Typhon, @penhaligons_london 's fragrance Luna is perfect: "The Moon Goddess’ bath is as soothing as it is seductive, much like her eau de toilette. It shines with orange, jasmine, soft rose and fir balsam. Relax. Sink in. Surrender has never felt so sweet." I certainly intend to sink into the luxurious scent, which is perfectly paired with Endymion (photo to come).
.
#ancientart #ancientmythology #greekmythology #romanmythology #luna #penhaligons #arthistory #moongoddess

node.text:
Calling all antique textile and vintage clothing collectors in New England!  Sunday, July 11th is the inaugural @threadbareshow at the Southbridge Hotel in Southbridge, MA (follow @threadbareshow or go to www.threadbareshow.com for more details). Here I wear a 1930s dress lounging atop a European tapestry surrounded by silk and gold embroidered Indo-Persian textiles of the 18th and 19th centuries.  Textile production was a large part of the ancient Egyptian economy. It took place primarily at the household level and was thus controlled predominantly by women, one facet of the commonly held title "mistress of the house." Swipe for a painting of weavers from the tomb of Khnumhotep II at Beni Hasan, in a facsimile by Norman de Garis Davies (@metmuseum 33.8.16). Four women spin thread and work the loom, while the standing woman oversees the production.  The standing woman's title is often translated "overseer of the canal (mr)," although in the context "overseer of servants (mr.t)" might be the actual meaning.  The first hieroglyph is the tongue of a cow, which is a playful writing of the title imy-r3 "that which is in the mouth," normally written phonetically with an m-own and r-mouth (hop over to @howtoreadhieroglyphs for a full explanation). I always enjoy how paintings on the walls of Egyptian tombs often show us aspects of day-to-day life, and then we can fill in details with surviving artifacts, like weaving implements and actual textiles.
.
#hieroglyphs #hieroglyphics #vintageclothing #vintagestyle #antiquetextile #1930s #1930sdress #ancientegypt
